name: What Kind of Career You Should Pursue
author: Michel Moreau
post:
If you google this question online, you will find that this question has been answered multiple times.

I bet many people will provide you with specific answers with a detailed explanation on how these professions fit your personality, skills, temperament. And this is fine – being conscious of your human nature is a good thing, and hopefully it will guide you toward a career you will enjoy.

There is one thing though - nobody will nor can decide for you in the end. A better approach at rapidly finding a career you enjoy is the following:

  • Learn broadly and constantly about many topics to form a deep view of the world you live in: psychology, philosophy, politics, engineering, mathematics, physics, arts, history, etc.
  • Find what problems are important to you and the people around you as your learning about the world progresses.
  • Determine the skills needed to fix these problems and acquire them.
  • Connect with people interested in solving the same problems you want to solve.
  • With your courage, patience, and self-directedness, be willing to try and actually fix the problems you care about, and try to surround yourself with critical but empowering influences wanting you to succeed. Self-directedness toward fixing the problems that matter to you with people sharing your view is your only path to having a career that will be meaningful to you in the end.

Don't waste too much time listening to other people's opinions. In the matter of career choices, do your own thinking.

name: A Very Strong Sign of Human Intelligence
author: Michel Moreau

name: On Being Rigid
author: Michel Moreau
post:
The personality traits that are usually harmful are the ones that are too rigid.

By rigid, I mean traits you display in multiple scenarios as an unconscious defense mechanism, that usually result in lasting and repeating negative consequences for yourself or your relationships.

Jeffrey E. Young, a clinical psychologist, professor at Columbia University, and inventor of Schema Therapy and the term lifetraps, wrote extensively about these rigid traits, namely in his book Reinventing Your Life, in which he describes the origin of these type of traits, the way they manifest, and how to have better control over these manifestations.

If you want to better understand your human nurture, how your past influences your present personality, digging into Jeffrey E. Young’s writings is a very good starting point.

Fairwell.
